headline.main: HEART ATTACK RISK UNRELATED TO NICOTINE LEVEL, STUDY SAYS

docs.lead_paragraph: A yearlong study of hospitalized heart attack patients has shown that the risk of suffering a heart attack was just as great among smokers who used low-nicotine cigarettes as it was among those who used high-nicotine brands. The new study, conducted among 508 patients hospitalized for myocardial infarction, the most common form of heart attack, indicated that smokers' higher risk of heart attack is apparently unrelated to the amounts of nicotine or carbon monoxide in the smoke of the different brands of cigarettes they inhaled. The study indicated that there were about as many heart attack victims among those who smoked cigarettes with as little nicotine as 0.8 milligrams per cigarette as there were among those who smoked brands containing more than 1.5 milligrams.
